Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Impacts of Land Use Patterns and Public Transit Availability on the Economic and Environmental Sustainability of Electric Vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Award from the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows Program) Dr. Elizabeth Traut from Carnegie-Mellon University will investigate the impacts of land use patterns and public transit availability on the adoption, use and economic/environmental sustainability of plug-in and hybrid electric vehicles (xEVs). This award has support from: the Directorate for Engineering, the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences and the Office of Integrative and International Activities.

The proposed work will investigate what scenarios of electric vehicles (xEVs) and charging infrastructure are most environmentally and economically sustainable in various regions, under both current and future electric grid mixes. Some of the factors that will be considered include: vehicle design (especially all-electric range), adoption (cost factors, subsidies), driving patterns (distance between charges, city vs. highway driving), charging
opportunities (when, where, and how long vehicles are parked), and charging infrastructure, which are in turn affected by regional factors such as land use patterns and public transit availability. The research will compare scenarios developed for Chicago and Glasgow, Scotland. The aim of studies like that proposed in this work is to develop science- and engineering-based frameworks to guide policy decisions for regional systems of xEVs and charging infrastructure.

Dr. Traut will be working with collaborators Prof. Chris Hendrickson of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Carnegie-Mellon University as well as Prof. Piyushimita Thakuriah, Halcrow Chair of Transport at the University of Glasgow.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined the impacts of existing land use patterns and public transit availability on life cycle GHG emissions of electric vehicle systems in a metropolitan area. By combining techniques from engineering and techniques from urban studies, we developed generalizable methods to identify correlations between existing land use patterns and transit availability and benefits that can be achieved by switching to electric vehicles. We applied these methods to a case study on greenhouse gas emissions from electric vehicles in Chicago, Illinois. These results have implications for local and regional policies on sustainable transportation, especially policies encouraging electric vehicle adoption as an approach to sustainable transportation. These methods can be used to examine the economic, environmental, and social sustainability of electric vehicles with the same underlying modeling for comparison purposes and can also be extended to analyze other systems to tackle the complex problems of sustainability. The methods also have the potential to identify social inequalities that may be related to vehicle electrification so that these can be addressed.

We also published a study addressing the lack of residential charging for electric vehicles and the ability of publicly accessible charging stations for electric vehicles to offset that lack. This study focused on the greater Chicago metropolitan area to model potential supply and demand of publicly accessible charging stations, especially near homes, to assess to what extent the current charging infrastructure can meet potential demand to offset lack of home charging availability and where additional public charging may be needed. We presented findings on the daily aggregate potential demand for public charging with a given adoption level of plug-in vehicles. These results have implications for local and regional policies on encouraging the availability of residential and public charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, including potential geographic distribution of infrastructure to accommodate overnight charging.

This project has brought to light several ways in which travel data could improve to support analysis of the benefits of electric vehicles. This information has been communicated to relevant data collectors in both the US and the UK to improve data availability for these purposes in the future. This research is informing some of the work of the Urban Big Data Centre at the University of Glasgow to link existing data sets to create more useful ones covering a variety of aspects of the same households.

This project established a new international and interdisciplinary research collaboration between the University of Glasgow and Carnegie Mellon University. This project developed the PI’s skills in sustainability by providing international and cross-disciplinary research opportunities. The PI gained extensive exposure to research and methods in Urban Studies and gained experience with GIS and geographical methods. The PI mentored a PhD student at the University of Glasgow and three MS students at Carnegie Mellon University. The project also included developing curriculum for high school students on electricity, electric vehicles, and sustainable transportation and teaching the curriculum to Pittsburgh area high school students including underrepresented groups on multiple occasions.
